children.name: D1.1.K-2
children.description: Explain why the compelling question is important to the student.

children.name: D1.2.K-2
children.description: Identify disciplinary ideas associated with a compelling question.

children.name: D1.3.K-2
children.description: Identify facts and concepts associated with a supporting question.

children.name: D1.4.K-2
children.description: Make connections between supporting questions and compelling questions.

children.name: D2.Civ.1.K-2
children.description: Describe roles and responsibilities of people in authority.

children.name: D2.Civ.10.K-2
children.description: Compare their own point of view with others’ perspectives.

children.name: D2.Civ.11.K-2
children.description: Explain how people can work together to make decisions in the classroom.

children.name: D2.Civ.12.K-2
children.description: Identify and explain how rules function in public (classroom and school) settings.

children.name: D2.Civ.14.K-2
children.description: Describe how people have tried to improve their communities over time.

children.name: D2.Civ.2.K-2
children.description: Explain how all people, not just official leaders, play important roles in a community.

children.name: D2.Civ.3.K-2
children.description: Explain the need for and purposes of rules in various settings inside and outside of school.

children.name: D2.Civ.4.K-2
children.description: Begins in grades 3–5

children.name: D2.Civ.5.K-2
children.description: Explain what governments are and some of their functions.

children.name: D2.Civ.6.K-2
children.description: Describe how communities work to accomplish common tasks, establish responsibilities, and fulfill roles of authority.

children.name: D2.Civ.7.K-2
children.description: Apply civic virtues when participating in school settings.

children.name: D2.Civ.8.K-2
children.description: Describe democratic principles such as equality, fairness, and respect for legitimate authority and rules.

children.name: D2.Civ.9.K-2
children.description: Follow agreed-upon rules for discussions while responding attentively to others when addressing ideas and making decisions as a group.

children.name: D2.Eco.1.K-2
children.description: Explain how scarcity necessitates decision making.

children.name: D2.Eco.10.K-2
children.description: Explain why people save.

children.name: D2.Eco.12.K-2
children.description: Describe examples of the goods and services that governments provide.

children.name: D2.Eco.13.K-2
children.description: Describe examples of capital goods and human capital.

children.name: D2.Eco.14.K-2
children.description: Describe why people in one country trade goods and services with people in other countries.

children.name: D2.Eco.15.K-2
children.description: Describe products that are produced abroad and sold domestically and products that are produced domestically and sold abroad.

children.name: D2.Eco.2.K-2
children.description: Identify the benefits and costs of making various personal decisions.

children.name: D2.Eco.3.K-2
children.description: Describe the skills and knowledge required to produce certain goods and services.

children.name: D2.Eco.4.K-2
children.description: Describe the goods and services that people in the local community produce and those that are produced in other communities.

children.name: D2.Eco.5.K-2
children.description: Identify prices of products in a local market.

children.name: D2.Eco.6.K-2
children.description: Explain how people earn income.

children.name: D2.Eco.7.K-2
children.description: Describe examples of costs of production.

children.name: D2.Eco.9.K-2
children.description: Describe the role of banks in an economy.

children.name: D2.Geo.1.K-2
children.description: Construct maps, graphs, and other representations of familiar places.

children.name: D2.Geo.10.K-2
children.description: Describe changes in the physical and cultural characteristics of various world regions.

children.name: D2.Geo.11.K-2
children.description: Explain how the consumption of products connects people to distant places.

children.name: D2.Geo.12.K-2
children.description: Identify ways that a catastrophic disaster may affect people living in a place.

children.name: D2.Geo.2.K-2
children.description: Use maps, graphs, photographs, and other representations to describe places and the relationships and interactions that shape them.

children.name: D2.Geo.3.K-2
children.description: Use maps, globes, and other simple geographic models to identify cultural and environmental characteristics of places.

children.name: D2.Geo.4.K-2
children.description: Explain how weather, climate, and other environmental characteristics affect people’s lives in a place or region.

children.name: D2.Geo.5.K-2
children.description: Describe how human activities affect the cultural and environmental characteristics of places or regions.

children.name: D2.Geo.6.K-2
children.description: Identify some cultural and environmental characteristics of specific places.

children.name: D2.Geo.7.K-2
children.description: Explain why and how people, goods, and ideas move from place to place.

children.name: D2.Geo.8.K-2
children.description: Compare how people in different types of communities use local and distant environments to meet their daily needs.

children.name: D2.Geo.9.K-2
children.description: Describe the connections between the physical environment of a place and the economic activities found there.

children.name: D2.His.1.K-2
children.description: Create a chronological sequence of multiple events.

children.name: D2.His.10.K-2
children.description: Explain how historical sources can be used to study the past.

children.name: D2.His.11.K-2
children.description: Identify the maker, date, and place of origin for a historical source from information within the source itself.

children.name: D2.His.12.K-2
children.description: Generate questions about a particular historical source as it relates to a particular historical event or development.

children.name: D2.His.14.K-2
children.description: Generate possible reasons for an event or development in the past.

children.name: D2.His.16.K-2
children.description: Select which reasons might be more likely than others to explain a historical event or development.

children.name: D2.His.2.K-2
children.description: Compare life in the past to life today.

children.name: D2.His.3.K-2
children.description: Generate questions about individuals and groups who have shaped a significant historical change.

children.name: D2.His.4.K-2
children.description: Compare perspectives of people in the past to those of people in the present.

children.name: D2.His.6.K-2
children.description: Compare different accounts of the same historical event.

children.name: D2.His.9.K-2
children.description: Identify different kinds of historical sources.

children.name: Evaluating Sources, Communicating Conclusions & Taking Action
D3.1.K-2
children.description: Gather relevant information from one or two sources while using the origin and structure to guide the selection.

children.name: D3.2.K-2
children.description: Evaluate a source by distinguishing between fact and opinion.

children.name: D4.1.K-2
children.description: Construct an argument with reasons.

children.name: D4.2.K-2
children.description: Construct explanations using correct sequence and relevant information.

children.name: D4.3.K-2
children.description: Present a summary of an argument using print, oral, and digital technologies.

children.name: D4.4.K-2
children.description: Ask and answer questions about arguments.

children.name: D4.5.K-2
children.description: Ask and answer questions about explanations.

children.name: D4.6.K-2
children.description: Identify and explain a range of local, regional, and global problems, and some ways in which people are trying to address these problems.

children.name: D4.7.K-2
children.description: Identify ways to take action to help address local, regional, and global problems.

children.name: D4.8.K-2
children.description: Use listening, consensus-building, and voting procedures to decide on and take action in their classrooms.
